title: Grade 8 Mathematics
teaser: Expressions and Equations, Functions, and Geometry

children.title: Integer Exponents and Scientific Notation
children.teaser: Students extending the properties of exponents to integer exponents.

children.title: Exponential Notation and Properties of Integer Exponents
children.teaser: Students learn precise definition of exponential notation.

children.title: Exponential Notation
children.teaser: Students know the reason for some bases requiring parentheses.

children.title: Multiplication of Numbers in Exponential Form
children.teaser: Students write equivalent numerical and symbolic expressions using the first law of exponents.

children.title: Numbers in Exponential Form Raised to a Power
children.teaser: Students write simplified, equivalent numeric, and symbolic expressions using this new knowledge of powers.

children.title: Applying Properties of Exponents to Generate Equivalent Expressions
children.teaser: Students know that a number raised to the zeroth power is equal to one.

children.title: Negative Exponents and the Laws of Exponents
children.teaser: Students know the definition of a number raised to a negative exponent.

children.title: Proofs of Laws of Exponents
children.teaser: Students extend the previous laws of exponents to include all integer exponents.

children.title: Magnitude and Scientific Notation
children.teaser: Students’ understanding of integer exponents is expanded to include magnitude as a measurement.

children.title: Magnitude
children.teaser: Students know the exponent of an expression provides information about the magnitude of a number.

children.title: Estimating Quantities
children.teaser: Students use their knowledge of ratios, fractions, and laws of exponents to simplify expressions.

children.title: Scientific Notation
children.teaser: In this lesson we learn how to write the number exactly, using scientific notation.

children.title: Operations with Numbers in Scientific Notation
children.teaser: Practicing operations with numbers in scientific notation and standard notation.

children.title: Efficacy of Scientific Notation
children.teaser: Students read, write, and perform operations on numbers expressed in scientific notation.

children.title: Choice of Unit
children.teaser: Students determine appropriate units for various measurements and rewrite measurements based on new units.

children.title: Comparing and Interpreting Scientific Notation Using Technology
children.teaser: Students compare numbers expressed in scientific notation.

children.title: The Concept of Congruence
children.teaser: Students experiment with rotations, reflections, and translations of geometrical figures.

children.title: Definitions and Properties of the Basic Rigid Motions
children.teaser: Students verify experimentally properties of the basic rigid motions.

children.title: Why Move Things Around?
children.teaser: Students are introduced to vocabulary and notation related to rigid motions (e.g., transformation, image, map).

children.title: Definition of Translation and Three Basic Properties
children.teaser: Students learn that translations preserve lengths of segments and degrees of angles.

children.title: Translating Lines
children.teaser: Students learn that translations map parallel lines to parallel lines.

children.title: Definition of Reflection and Basic Properties
children.teaser: Students know the definition of reflection and perform reflections across a line using a transparency.

children.title: Definition of Rotation and Basic Properties
children.teaser: Students know how to rotate a figure a given degree around a given center.

children.title: Rotations of 180 Degrees
children.teaser: Learning rotation of 180 degrees moves a point on the coordinate plane (a,b) to (-a,-b).

children.title: Sequencing the Basic Rigid Motions
children.teaser: Students learn to sequence combinations of rigid motions while maintaining basic properties of individual rigid motions.

children.title: Sequencing Translations
children.teaser: Students learn about the sequence of transformations (one move on the plane followed by another).

children.title: Sequencing Reflections and Translations
children.teaser: Students learn that the reflection is its own inverse transformation.

children.title: Sequencing Rotations
children.teaser: Sequences of rotations preserve lengths of segments as well as degrees of measures of angles.

children.title: Sequences of Rigid Motions
children.teaser: Students describe a sequence of rigid motions that maps one figure onto another.

children.title: Congruence and Angle Relationships
children.teaser: Students learn that congruence is just a sequence of basic rigid motions.

children.title: Definition of Congruence and Some Basic Properties
children.teaser: Basic properties of congruence are similar to properties for all rigid motions (translations, rotations, reflections).

children.title: Angles Associated with Parallel Lines
children.teaser: Presenting arguments to conclude about angles formed when parallel lines are cut by a transversal.

children.title: Angle Sum of a Triangle
children.teaser: Students present informal arguments to draw conclusions about the angle sum of a triangle.

children.title: More on the Angles of a Triangle
children.teaser: Students know a third informal proof of the angle sum theorem.

children.title: The Pythagorean Theorem (Optional)
children.teaser: Students begin the learning of Pythagorean Theorem.

children.title: Informal Proof of the Pythagorean Theorem
children.teaser: Introduction to the Pythagorean theorem and showing an informal proof of the theorem.

children.title: Applications of the Pythagorean Theorem
children.teaser: Students use the Pythagorean theorem to determine missing side lengths of right triangles.

children.title: Similarity: Geometry
children.teaser: Students learn about dilation and similarity.

children.title: Dilation
children.teaser: Students define and deepen understanding of dilation.

children.title: “What Lies Behind Same Shape”?
children.teaser: Students know that dilations magnify and shrink figures.

children.title: Properties of Dilations
children.teaser: Students learn how to use a compass and a ruler to perform dilations.

children.title: Examples of Dilations
children.teaser: Students know that dilations map circles to circles and ellipses to ellipses.

children.title: Fundamental Theorem of Similarity (FTS)
children.teaser: Students experimentally verify the properties related to the fundamental theorem of similarity (FTS).

children.title: First Consequences of FTS
children.teaser: Students verify the converse of the fundamental theorem of similarity experimentally.

children.title: Dilations on the Coordinate Plane
children.teaser: Students describe the effect of dilations on two-dimensional figures using coordinates.

children.title: Informal Proofs of Properties of Dilations
children.teaser: Students know an informal proof of why dilations are angle-preserving transformations.

children.title: Similar Figures
children.teaser: Students learn definition of similarity and the properties of similarities.

children.title: Similarity
children.teaser: Students define similarity and why dilation alone is not enough to determine similarity.

children.title: Basic Properties of Similarity
children.teaser: Similarity is both a symmetric and a transitive relation.

children.title: Informal Proof of AA Criterion for Similarity
children.teaser: Students know an informal proof of the angle-angle (AA) criterion for similar triangles.

children.title: More About Similar Triangles
children.teaser: Students present informal arguments as to whether or not two triangles are similar.

children.title: Modeling Using Similarity
children.teaser: Students see how the mathematics they have learned in this module relates to real-world problems.

children.title: The Pythagorean Theorem (Intro)
children.teaser: Students to learn about the Pythagorean Theorem and itsapplication.

children.title: Proof of the Pythagorean Theorem
children.teaser: The following proof of the Pythagorean theorem is based on the fact similarity is transitive.

children.title: The Converse of the Pythagorean Theorem (Intro)
children.teaser: Students apply the Pythagorean Theorem and its converse to solve problems.

children.title: Linear Equations
children.teaser: Students extend what they already know about unit rates and proportional relationships to linear equations and their graphs.

children.title: Writing and Solving Linear Equations
children.teaser: Students transcribe written statements using symbolic notation.

children.title: Writing Equations Using Symbols
children.teaser: Students write mathematical statements using symbols to represent numbers.

children.title: Linear and Nonlinear Expressions in x
children.teaser: Distinguishing linear expressions from nonlinear expressions because we will soon be solving linear equations.

children.title: Linear Equations in x
children.teaser: Students know that a linear equation is a statement of equality between two expressions.

children.title: Solving a Linear Equation
children.teaser: Validate the use of the properties of equality by having students share their thoughts.

children.title: Writing and Solving Linear Equations
children.teaser: Students apply knowledge of geometry to writing and solving linear equations.

children.title: Solutions of a Linear Equation
children.teaser: Students learn that not every linear equation has a solution.

children.title: Classification of Solutions
children.teaser: Conditions for a linear equation has a unique solution, no solution, or infinitely many solutions.

children.title: Linear Equations in Disguise
children.teaser: Students learn some equations may not look like linear equations are, in fact, linear.

children.title: An Application of Linear Equations
children.teaser: The purpose of this lesson is to expose students to applications of linear equations.

children.title: Linear Equations in Two Variables and Their Graphs
children.teaser: Students work with proportional relationships related to average speed and constant speed.

children.title: A Critical Look at Proportional Relationships
children.teaser: Students use linear equations in two variables to answer questions about distance and time.

children.title: Constant Rate
children.teaser: Students graph points on a coordinate plane related to constant rate problems.

children.title: Linear Equations in Two Variables
children.teaser: Students use a table to find solutions to a linear equation.

children.title: The Graph of a Linear Equation in Two Variables
children.teaser: As students provide solutions, organize them in an x-y table.

children.title: The Graph of a Linear Equation—Horizontal and Vertical Lines
children.teaser: Graphing and exploring the connection between ax+by=c and x=c.

children.title: Slope and Equations of Lines
children.teaser: Students understand that the slope of a line describes the rate of change of a line.

children.title: The Slope of a Non-Vertical Line
children.teaser: Students interpret the unit rate as the slope of a graph.

children.title: The Computation of the Slope of a Non-Vertical Line
children.teaser: Students use the slope formula to compute the slope of a non-vertical line.

children.title: The Line Joining Two Distinct Points of the Graph
children.teaser: Students transform the standard form of an equation into y=-a/b x+c/b.

children.title: Only One Line Passing Through a Point with a Slope
children.teaser: Students graph equations in the form of y=mx+b using information about slope and y-intercept point.

children.title: Graph of Linear Equation in Two Variables Is a Line
children.teaser: Students graph linear equations on the coordinate plane.

children.title: Every Line Is a Graph of a Linear Equation
children.teaser: Students write the linear equation whose graph is a given line.

children.title: Some Facts About Graphs of Linear Equations in Two Variables
children.teaser: Students know the traditional forms of the slope formula and slope-intercept equation.

children.title: Constant Rates Revisited
children.teaser: Constant rate problems are linear equation in two variables where graph slope is constant rate.

children.title: The Defining Equation of a Line
children.teaser: Two equations ax+by=c and a'x+b'y=c' graph as the same line when one is nonzero.

children.title: Systems of Linear Equations and Their Solutions
children.teaser: Students explore simultaneous equations and their solutions.

children.title: Introduction to Simultaneous Equations
children.teaser: Students learn the notation for simultaneous equations.

children.title: Geometric Interpretation of the Solutions of a Linear System
children.teaser: Sketching graphs of two linear equations finding the point of intersection. Identifying lines as solution.

children.title: Characterization of Parallel Lines
children.teaser: The Discussion is an optional proof of the theorem about parallel lines.

children.title: Nature of Solutions of a System of Linear Equations
children.teaser: Students know a strategy for solving a system of linear equations algebraically.

children.title: Another Computational Method of Solving a Linear System
children.teaser: Students learn the elimination method for solving a system of linear equations.

children.title: Word Problems
children.teaser: Students write word problems into systems of linear equations.

children.title: Conversion Between Celsius and Fahrenheit
children.teaser: Consistency using repeated reasoning leading them to the general equation for conversion between Celsius, Fahrenheit.

children.title: Pythagorean Theorem (Optional)
children.teaser: Students explore Pythagorean triples.

children.title: System of Equations Leading to Pythagorean Triples
children.teaser: System of equations to find three numbers, a, b, c, (a2 + b2 = c2).

children.title: Examples of Functions from Geometry
children.teaser: Students understand why functions are necessary for describing geometric concepts and occurrences.

children.title: Functions
children.teaser: Students discover the important role functions play in making predictions.

children.title: The Concept of a Function
children.teaser: Students use proportions to analyze the reasoning involved.

children.title: Formal Definition of a Function
children.teaser: Students know that a function assigns to each input exactly one output.

children.title: Linear Functions and Proportionality
children.teaser: Students relate constant speed and proportional relationships to linear functions using information from a table.

children.title: More Examples of Functions
children.teaser: Examine and recognize real-world functions as discrete functions, such as the cost of a book.

children.title: Graphs of Functions and Equations
children.teaser: Understanding the graph of a function is identical to the graph of a certain equation.

children.title: Graphs of Linear Functions and Rate of Change
children.teaser: Students use rate of change to determine if a function is a linear function.

children.title: Comparing Linear Functions and Graphs
children.teaser: Using rate of change to compare functions, determining which has a greater rate of change.

children.title: Graphs of Simple Nonlinear Functions
children.teaser: Students determine whether an equation is linear or nonlinear by examining the rate of change.

children.title: Volume
children.teaser: Students explore the volume and formulas for cones, cylinders, and spheres.

children.title: Examples of Functions from Geometry
children.teaser: Students write rules to express functions related to geometry.

children.title: Volumes of Familiar Solids―Cones and Cylinders
children.teaser: Students know the volume formulas for cones and cylinders.

children.title: Volume of a Sphere
children.teaser: Students apply the formula for the volume of a sphere to real-world and mathematical problems.

children.title: Linear Functions
children.teaser: Students are introduced to bivariate data.

children.title: Study of Linear Functions
children.teaser: Students examine the relationship between two variables using linear functions.

children.title: Modeling Linear Relationships
children.teaser: Students interpret linear functions based on the context of a problem.

children.title: Interpreting Rate of Change and Initial Value
children.teaser: Students interpret the constant rate of change and initial value of a line in context.

children.title: Representations of a Line
children.teaser: Graphing a line specified by two points of a linear relationship, providing the linear function.

children.title: Increasing and Decreasing Functions
children.teaser: Students describe qualitatively the functional relationship between two types of quantities by analyzing a graph.

children.title: Increasing and Decreasing Functions (Continued)
children.teaser: Students qualitatively describe the functional relationship between two types of quantities by analyzing a graph.

children.title: Bivariate Numerical Data
children.teaser: Students model the relationship between two quantitative variables.

children.title: Scatter Plots
children.teaser: Students understand that a trend in a scatterplot does not establish cause-and-effect.

children.title: Patterns in Scatter Plots
children.teaser: Students identify and describe unusual features in scatter plots, such as clusters and outliers.

children.title: Informally Fitting a Line
children.teaser: Students informally fit a straight line to data displayed in a scatter plot.

children.title: Linear and Nonlinear Models
children.teaser: Students interpret linear and nonlinear models.

children.title: Determining the Equation of a Line Fit to Data
children.teaser: Students make predictions based on the equation of a line fit to data.

children.title: Linear Models
children.teaser: Students interpret slope and the initial value in a data context.

children.title: Using Linear Models in a Data Context
children.teaser: Students recognize and justify that a linear model can be used to fit data.

children.title: Bivariate Categorical Data
children.teaser: Students determine relative frequencies.

children.title: Nonlinear Models in a Data Context (Optional)
children.teaser: Students draw nonlinear functions that are consistent with a verbal description of a nonlinear relationship.

children.title: Summarizing Bivariate Categorical Data in a Two-Way Table
children.teaser: Students organize bivariate categorical data into a two-way table.

children.title: Association Between Categorical Variables
children.teaser: Students consider whether conclusions are reasonable based on a two-way table.

children.title: Introduction to Irrational Numbers Using Geometry
children.teaser: Students explain a proof of the Pythagorean Theorem on their own.

children.title: Square and Cube Roots
children.teaser: Students learn the notation related to roots.

children.title: The Pythagorean Theorem
children.teaser: This lesson assumes knowledge of the theorem and its basic applications.

children.title: Square Roots
children.teaser: Students approximate the location of square roots on the number line.

children.title: Existence and Uniqueness of Square and Cube Roots
children.teaser: The positive square root and cube root exists for all positive numbers and is unique.

children.title: Simplifying Square Roots
children.teaser: Students use factors of a number to simplify a square root.

children.title: Solving Radical Equations
children.teaser: Solving equations that required finding the square root or cube root of a number.

children.title: Decimal Expansions of Numbers
children.teaser: Students explore decimal expansions and irrational numbers.

children.title: Finite and Infinite Decimals
children.teaser: Students will be exposed to the concepts of finite and infinite decimals here.

children.title: Infinite Decimals
children.teaser: Students know the intuitive meaning of an infinite decimal.

children.title: The Long Division Algorithm
children.teaser: Students know that every rational number has a decimal expansion that repeats eventually.

children.title: Decimal Expansions of Fractions, Part 1
children.teaser: Applying knowledge of equivalent fractions, long division, distributive property to write decimal expansion of fractions.

children.title: Converting Repeating Decimals to Fractions
children.teaser: Students convert a decimal expansion that eventually repeats into a fraction.

children.title: The Decimal Expansion of Some Irrational Numbers
children.teaser: Students distinguish between rational and irrational numbers based on decimal expansions.

children.title: Decimal Expansions of Fractions, Part 2
children.teaser: Students relate the method of rational approximation to the long division algorithm.

children.title: Comparison of Irrational Numbers
children.teaser: Students place irrational numbers in their approximate locations on a number line.

children.title: The Decimal Expansion of π
children.teaser: Students estimate the value of expressions such as〖 π〗^2.

children.title: The Pythagorean Theorem
children.teaser: Students learn another proof of the Pythagorean Theorem.

children.title: The Pythagorean Theorem, Revisited
children.teaser: Students explain a proof of the Pythagorean Theorem.

children.title: The Converse of the Pythagorean Theorem
children.teaser: Students apply the theorem and its converse to solve problems.

children.title: Distance on the Coordinate Plane
children.teaser: Students may benefit from physically measuring lengths to understand finding distance.

children.title: Applications of the Pythagorean Theorem
children.teaser: Students apply the Pythagorean Theorem.

children.title: Applications of Radicals and Roots
children.teaser: Students learn that radical expressions naturally arise in geometry.

children.title: Cones and Spheres
children.teaser: Using the Pythagorean Theorem to determine an unknown dimension of a cone or a sphere.

children.title: Truncated Cones
children.teaser: Students find the volume of truncated cones.

children.title: Volume of Composite Solids
children.teaser: Volumes can be added as long as the solids do not overlap their figures.

children.title: Average Rate of Change
children.teaser: Students will reach an important conclusion about constant rate and average rate of change.

children.title: Nonlinear motion
children.teaser: Students use what they learned about solving multi-step equations which requires knowledge of integer exponents.
